data.title: The Andy Roberts Quintet reaches for the sky
data.meta_description: Andy Roberts’ new album has an eclectic mix of original and cover tunes that share one common thread: They’re good songs.“I like to do arrangements of anything from old tunes by Fats Waller to tunes by Pink Floyd,” said Roberts who will appear with his quintet Saturday night at Building 24 Live in Wyomissing. “I […]
data.text:
For information on submitting an obituary, please contact Reading Eagle by phone at 610-371-5018, or email at obituaries@readingeagle.com or fax at 610-371-5193.

Most obituaries published in the Reading Eagle are submitted through funeral homes and cremation services, but we will accept submissions from families. Obituaries can be emailed to obituaries@readingeagle.com.

In addition to the text of the obituary, any photographs that you wish to include can be attached to this email. Please put the text of the obituary in a Word document, a Google document or in the body of the email. The Reading Eagle also requires a way to verify the death, so please include either the phone number of the funeral home or cremation service that is in charge of the deceased's care or a photo of his/her death certificate. We also request that your full name, phone number and address are all included in this email.

All payments by families must be made with a credit card. We will send a proof of the completed obituary before we require payment. The obituary cannot run, however, until we receive payment in full.

Obituaries can be submitted for any future date, but they must be received no later than 3:00 p.m. the day prior to its running for it to be published.

Please call the obituary desk, at 610-371-5018, for information on pricing.

Andy Roberts’ new album has an eclectic mix of original and cover tunes that share one common thread: They’re good songs.

“I like to do arrangements of anything from old tunes by Fats Waller to tunes by Pink Floyd,” said Roberts who will appear with his quintet Saturday night at Building 24 Live in Wyomissing. “I re-arrange the songs to make them more conducive to the jazz style, but it doesn’t matter how you play them, they are good songs either way.”

Roberts’ Building 24 performance will be in support of “Reach for the Sky,” his second CD, but the first for the quintet.

“This is our first outing as a group,” he said, adding that the new CD will be available for purchase at the venue.

The quintet also includes John Riley on drums, Tom Strohman on sax and flute, Hector Rosado on percussion and Steve Meashey on bass.

The title, he said, describes what he tries to do with all the different types of music he plays.

“I look at it as something that we all do,” he said. “We try to improve ourselves and our craft. We are always stretching and reaching for that next goal.”

It has been that way for Roberts since he first played around on a piano as a child.

“I started lessons when I was very young,” he said. “But I remember playing before I ever took a lesson. My mother played piano so we always had one.”

He said he started lessons officially when he was about 6, but was banging around on the piano a couple years before that.

“I enjoyed exploring the keyboard,” Roberts said. “That’s how I still look at it. I’m in love with exploring the keyboard. It always felt very natural for me.”

By the time he was 14 he was playing in his brother’s rock band.

“That’s when I learned you could make money doing this stuff,” he said. “It was mostly playing the local VFW and then some places that I probably wasn’t legally allowed to be.”

The experience solidified his dream of being a musician, so he attended the Berklee School of Music (where daughter Nicole currently follows in his footsteps) and worked on both performance and the business side of things.

“Berklee is known for contemporary music styles,” he said. “Especially jazz. So it was a good fit for me.”

He has expanded since then to include music direction at several theaters, including the American Music Theatre and Prima in Lancaster and The Timbers in Mount Gretna.

“I do enjoy the process of all those different things,” he said. “I love developing a show, getting a cast together and seeing how things gel, then rehearsing and putting it in front of an audience.”

Roberts enjoys taking all different types of music and filtering it through his jazz ears to create something new, yet still familiar.

“I almost hate to say jazz pianist,” he said. “Because I’m certainly a rock-and-roll guy as well. I stay true to the music that influenced me and that would be considered classic jazz. But once you know the structure of the song and you’ve stated the melody, then you can improvise and that’s essentially what we do. So really I just try to approach it that way and let my influences dictate the music.”

It works for him, too.

“I think (jazz) sometimes finds you,” he said. “It’s always been there, and I feel lucky that there is a thing that I love to do that is also my work.”

Email Tracy Rasmussen: weekend@readingeagle.com.

Originally Published: May 21, 2015 at 1:00 a.m.
